awd_titl_txt: Belmont Forum Collaborative Research Food-Water-Energy Nexus: The Moveable Nexus: Design-led urban food, water and energy management innovation in new boundary conditions of change
awd_abstract_narration:
Many cities across the globe are facing difficult challenges managing their food, water and energy systems. The challenges stem from the fact that the issues of food, water and energy are often tightly connected with each other, not only locally but also globally. This is known as the Food-Water-Energy (FWE) nexus.  An effective solution to a local water problem may cause new local problems with food or energy, or cause new water problems at the global level. On a local scale, it is difficult to anticipate whether solutions to one issue in the nexus are sustainable across food, water and energy systems, both at the local and the global scale.  Innovative solutions that encompass the nexus are particularly important to enable cities to better manage their food, water and energy systems and understand the benefits and tradeoffs for different solutions.  

This award supports U.S. researchers participating in a project competitively selected by a 29-country initiative through the joint Belmont Forum- Joint Programming Initiative (JPI) Urban Europe.  The Sustainable Urbanization Global Initiative (SUGI)/Food-Water-Energy Nexus is a multilateral initiative designed to support research projects that bring together the fragmented research and expertise across the globe to find innovative solutions to the Food-Water-Energy Nexus challenge.  The call seeks to develop more resilient, applied urban solutions to benefit a much wider range of stakeholders. The rapid urbanization of the world's population underscores the importance of this focus. International partners were invited to develop solutions for this challenge.  The funds requested will be used to support U.S. participants to cooperate in consortia that consist of partners from at least three of the participating countries and that bring together natural scientists, social scientists and research users (e.g., civil society, NGOs, and industry).  Participants from other countries are funded through their national funding organizations. 

This projects seeks to develop a FEW system incorporating the localized production of healthy food.  The production and consumption of healthy food is constrained by both future climate change and current diets: the project aims to mitigate these by designing strategies for the localization of healthy food production and test these within the context of far-future climate impacts. The scale at which this production is localized differs in each location, spanning scales from a single rooftop to an entire metropolitan region. The design outputs will be used as cornerstones of the entire field of possible solutions and are used to inspire other places to engage with these issues. Integrated within the program of stakeholder workshops is the development of an analytical decision-support tool, the M-NEX. Each successive workshop adds complexity and detail to the tool which aims to support decision-making in the planning and integration of local food production.  The project uses a research-based design approach to develop inspiring urban solutions in six differing regions across the world. The new knowledge generated in each of these projects will be used incrementally to develop an analytical decision support tool that will help integrate FEW solutions in future urban designs and developments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project formed part of an international design research collaboration supported by The Sustainable Urbanisation Global Initiative (SUGI)/Food-Water-Energy (FEW) Nexus program jointly established by the Belmont Forum and Urban Europe. The FEW Nexus is a perspective emerging from environmental science that aims to advance sustainability, resilience and circularity with specific focus on the intersections and interactions between food, energy and water systems. Researchers from the University of Michigan, TU Delft, Queens University Belfast, KEIO University and Qatar University were supported by their respective national agencies to develop a set of design processes, assessment, design and evaluation tools to assist with the application of FEW Nexus approaches to the design of urban intensification within precincts that prioritize urban agricultural production, food access, and energy and water system efficiencies that result in the reduction of CO2e per capita within proposed urban design schemes. Each team developed projects with stakeholder partners through series of living labs (sites for assessment, design proposals and evaluations) in the cities of Detroit MI, Amsterdam NL, Belfast UK, Tokyo JP, and Doha QA respectively. Work in this project was focused on Detroit.

 This project has produced new transformational methods and tools for the design, analysis, construction, verification, configuration, and deployment of FEW Nexus based urban developments across a range of scales and urban contexts. Key outcomes of the work include the development of several open-source tools processes. These tools are accessible to a large community of academic researchers, professional practitioners and municipal planning agencies without requiring specialized expertise in formal methods. The project has also produced explanatory videos for tool utilization. These include:

(i)          Multiscalar Mapping techniques to support the definition of FEW systems, contexts and parameters.

(ii)         MultiModal Access Mapping Tools for application to issues of food access.

(iii)        FEW Material Flows and Interactions Visualizations to illuminate contexts for design interventions.

(iv)        FEW Actor-Network Mapping Process and application to online tools to illuminate locations for system alteration.

(v)         FEW Design Toolkit for participatory co-creation and stakeholder engagement processes

(vi)        A system evaluation and impact quantification tool named ?FEWPrint? (codeveloped with TUDelft team)

During the course of the project and to support cross-team collaboration, a series of design-led workshops were held (in person and online due to Covid-19 pandemic) in each of the cities and involved stakeholder engagement with the international teams to illuminate the interaction of governance and socio-economic policy activities with the resource flows related to food, water, and energy.  The workshops explored novel and practical solutions for the complex challenges, prototyped design processes using the rapidly evolving knowledge base, and supported the development of advanced indicators and assessment tools needed for a comprehensive understanding of the urban FEW-Nexus.

Through this project urban design schemes were developed and assessed for two existing proposal sites with community partners and two speculative schemes for precincts currently undergoing development pressure and change. These include the Oakland Avenue Urban Farm, a 6-acre urban farm and cultural incubation space surrounded by medium and low density housing prototypes; Recovery Park, an industrial scaled urban farming campus providing housing for urban agricultural workers in recovery and mediating agricultural functions with green-blue public space models; Eastern Market, an intensive ?food innovation hub? coupling high density housing with mixed use food and market related programs; and Riverbend, a super-block scaled collective farming cooperative that produces new formats of public interface at its perimeter. For each, Quantification of systemic impacts is presented alongside visualizations of resulting building and public space typologies, engineering components, and new formats of public space that surface and center FEW circular systems as a means towards more sustainable and livable models of urbanism that reduce per capita CO2e.

The design research activities, processes and tools and outcomes were a core part of curriculum development for a new post-professional graduate course in Urban Design where students gained knowledge regarding use and application in their urban design proposals. The contributions of the graduate students funded by this project have been recognized and led to a 100% success rate in post project employment at professional design firms and additional doctoral studies related to the content of the project. Several female and under-represented minority students have participated in the project.

The design process methods, tools and techniques developed during the course of this project have been disseminated through a book chapter in an important academic press, an article in a highly regarding peer-reviewed journal, made available publicly both online and through stakeholder presentations in Detroit, and internationally in Paris FR and Calgary CA at peer-reviewed conference venues attended by academic researchers, design professionals, municipal panning authorities and mayors.

Overall, the project has contributed to the increased awareness and adoption of the principles of FEW Nexus based urban design processes and practices  developing novel approaches to the advancement of sustainable design through practical implementation of FEW Nexus..
